images.copyright: Thorny Devil (Moloch horridus) in Watarrka National Park, Northern Territory (© Yva Momatiuk and John Eastcott/Minden Pictures)
images.title: The devil you know
images.caption: The devil you know
images.copyrightonly: © Yva Momatiuk and John Eastcott/Minden Pictures
images.desc: Don’t let their appearance fool you – Thorny Devils are actually less prickly than you might think. In fact, the endemic creature’s spiky exterior (each of which is said to be similar in size to a rose thorn) actually helps them absorb water in their arid habitat. This can be obtained via dew that condenses on their body overnight or by brushing up against dew-heavy grass. This water then finds its way into the various grooves around the Thorny Devil’s body, and makes its way to the mouth via capillary action.
